document.title: NCHS - U.S. History Content Standards for Grades 5 - 12 (Eras 1 to 5, Origins to Reconstruction)

jurisdiction.title: National Center for History in the Schools

79105390A72E47CB81F6A9A42867E003.description: Evaluate the effects of northern capital and entrepreneurship on economic development in the postwar South. [Consider multiple perspectives]

959A48610FC04FD69AEE2911DDD6FDF4.description: Evaluate Reconstruction ideals as a culminating expression of the mid-19th-century impulse of social democratization and perfectionism. [Evaluate major debates among historians]

746673C018FF452BAE842D65956043C5.description: Analyze how the Civil War and Reconstruction changed men’s and women’s roles and status in the North, South, and West. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

D88501B349994BD38B24C2E27DEB6881.description: Assess how the political and economic position of African Americans in the northern and western states changed during Reconstruction. [Examine historical perspectives]

9B7A63266DE24A36B26DF3023AE945CB.description: Assess the progress of “Black Reconstruction” and legislative reform programs promoted by reconstructed state governments. [Marshal evidence of antecedent circumstances]

63AC32A26C4149CCAB371FC5CD74FC0D.description: Evaluate why corruption increased in the postwar period. [Analyze multiple causation]

9E9F7404DEA64801A60EC0F642C8749F.description: Reconstruction: Successes & Failures: The student understands the successes and failures of Reconstruction in the South, North, and West.

CCE5E861568140C9B2002C43C3786DB3.description: Describe the ways in which African Americans laid foundations for modern black communities during Reconstruction. [Hypothesize the influence of the past]

45C69F7D2D7E4411BA40D301824A73DB.description: Analyze how African Americans attempted to improve their economic position during Reconstruction and explain the factors involved in their quest for land ownership. [Analyze multiple causation]

C1730D67E25C40FA97F8D05383186431.description: Explain the economic and social problems facing the South and appraise their impact on different social groups. [Examine historical perspectives]

568C3AD19737436CBF63E86F78784A1D.description: Evaluate the goals and accomplishments of the Freedmen’s Bureau. [Hold interpretations of history as tentative]

84D5F8A36A014CACBAD16BD0B63EC2DD.description: Reconstruction: Southern Social Impact: The student understands the Reconstruction programs to transform social relations in the South.

17F48A6F93D54B258FEC94667CBFCD68.description: Analyze the role of violence and the tactics of the “redeemers” in regaining control over the southern state governments. [Interrogating historical data]

37D0A07DD58E45C1B74D9A32F3876E8C.description: Analyze the escalating conflict between the president and Congress and explain the reasons for and consequences of Johnson’s impeachment and trial. [Consider multiple perspectives]

56F2A9567E954916A57C743A546BBF30.description: Contrast the Reconstruction policies advocated by Lincoln, Andrew Johnson, and sharply divided Congressional leaders, while assessing these policies as responses to changing events. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

0427BBB69F2A4D8DAB08FD0D76F15E03.description: Analyze how shared values of the North and South limited support for social and racial democratization, as reflected in the Compromise of 1877. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

4CA05D32CAD846FCB0CAB6C3149C0600.description: Explain the provisions of the 14th and 15th amendments and the political forces supporting and opposing each. [Consider multiple perspectives]

3CC1D8585E0041098E981E768A4A2AE5.description: Reconstruction: Political Controversy: The student understands the political controversy over Reconstruction.

C36FCFA197994E6781A1EA5947F075D8.description: Evaluate the Union’s reasons for curbing wartime civil liberties. [Consider multiple perspectives]

92BED309E05C46548EAB236039F300E1.description: Analyze the reasons for the northern draft riots. [Analyze multiple causation]

28C327912D494EE98784231CB9742AE7.description: Compare the motives for fighting and the daily life experiences of Confederate with those of white and African American Union soldiers. [Evidence historical perspectives]

F8A6713AA4D946B28CF79237F367F3B7.description: Compare the human and material costs of the war in the North and South and assess the degree to which the war reunited the nation. [Examine historical perspectives]

32EBFC73CCA64A95A0130BF0E40F35A1.description: Compare women’s homefront and battlefront roles in the Union and the Confederacy. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

5DFE51E00D59457D941F661765C957D4.description: Civil War: Social Experience: The student understands the social experience of the war on the battlefield and homefront.

E3237DFCB1794B29A5733D54CFE67EE8.description: Describe the position of the major Indian nations during the Civil War and explain the effects of the war upon these nations. [Reconstruct patterns of historical succession and duration]

9119047E8E2548599AB246EE25C49729.description: Analyze the purpose, meaning, and significance of the Gettysburg Address. [Identify the author of the historical document and assess its credibility]

8D3C79A1CB8F4CAE9C871317D83A47DE.description: Compare the human resources of the Union and the Confederacy at the beginning of the Civil War and assess the tactical advantages of each side. [Utilize visual and mathematical data]

971BC5B3FFD549528B24EF9756427E8F.description: Evaluate provisions of the Emancipation Proclamation, Lincoln’s reasons for issuing it, and its significance. [Examine the influence of ideas]

5093F4B2B5AB4610AB6F72EA000AAE67.description: Identify the turning points of the war and evaluate how political, military, and diplomatic leadership affected the outcome of the conflict. [Assess the importance of the individual in history]

321F6CB0F66D4A85A63766BE6B343B0D.description: Identify the innovations in military technology and explain their impact on humans, property, and the final outcome of the war. [Utilize visual and mathematical data]

1314A3DB55E9469E88428E6B3F0A4D8D.description: Civil War - Resource Allocation: The student understands how the resources of the Union and Confederacy affected the course of the war.

34C3114ACCDE456592B531D29A0766B7.description: Analyze how the disruption of the second American party system frayed the durable bonds of union, leading to the ascent of the Republican party in the 1850s. [Analyze multiple causation]

10AF6D0071624128807601CB254DD70F.description: Chart the secession of the southern states and explain the process and reasons for secession. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

BF9834CCC46F48C4A86B9A1A6CDF0D12.description: Analyze the importance of the “free labor” ideology in the North and its appeal in preventing the further extension of slavery in the new territories. [Examine the influence of ideas]

B855F6F912C14A76BF3D26C55DAEDB7C.description: Explain how events after the Compromise of 1850 and the Dred Scott decision in 1857 contributed to increasing sectional polarization. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

B9636D7A7AEE40AAAE247C69C08FB637.description: Identify and explain the economic, social, and cultural differences between the North and the South. [Draw upon quantitative data to trace historical developments]

319D0E9C946D4D2B95C64B783FBBDC65.description: Explain the causes of the Civil War and evaluate the importance of slavery as a principal cause of the conflict. [Compare competing historical narratives]

504170F156D241D7AF265751E20B676B.description: Causes of the Civil War: The student understands how the North and South differed and how politics and ideologies led to the Civil War.

AF7C17D8F7D4495CBCA9EC9A6FC5B77B.description: Compare the North, South, and West in terms of men’s and women’s occupations, legal rights, and social status. [Interrogate historical data]

6AA753D31D874D22B180E7B9AC4AABAC.description: Compare and contrast the antebellum women’s movement for equality and 20th-century feminism. [Hypothesize the influence of the past]

5F6249CA424545308842D529A897C126.description: Analyze the goals of the 1848 Seneca Falls “Declaration of Sentiments” and evaluate its impact. [Reconstruct the literal meaning of a historical passage]

A75E79F1C72A437683D0E590FEEDD5D8.description: Analyze the activities of women of different racial and social groups in the reform movements for education, abolition, temperance, and women’s suffrage. [Examine the importance of the individual]

B5B6119C527B43C1A08F699EB59827E5.description: Gender Roles & Women: The student understands changing gender roles and the ideas and activities of women reformers.

7957B9ABE6E04ECB8DAD63935AD58F8F.description: Identify the major utopian experiments and analyze the reasons for their formation. [Consider multiple perspectives]

F1D74663C2B64F70881895F2D187642B.description: Define Transcendentalism, account for the rise of the first American renaissance, and analyze ideas concerning the individual, society, and nature expressed in the literary works of major Transcendentalists. [Examine the influence of ideas]

A9823379A1B54403AB0811650C3AAA66.description: Assess how the Second Great Awakening impinged on antebellum issues such as public education, temperance, women’s suffrage, abolition, and commercialization. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

C58D4E0F16B34314AC1CE68ED6E50DAF.description: Explain the importance of the Second Great Awakening and the ideas of its principal leaders. [Examine the influence of ideas]

79EF489389A64A2C8FD0357E90C1CFBA.description: Examine how literary and artistic movements fostered a distinct American identity among different groups and in different regions. [Draw upon literary and artistic sources]

3D370BF2BA4848508B2BCA5F4D082E59.description: Reform Movements: The student understands how Americans strived to reform society and create a distinct culture.

DA9BE0B105E34E7D9E4099ED8DF43E2A.description: Compare the positions of African American and white abolitionists on the issue of the African American’s place in society. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

339F02233193471FBB52C6AAF375E716.description: Analyze changing ideas about race and assess the reception of proslavery and antislavery ideologies in the North and South. [Examine the influence of ideas]

4E5D763E79734260ACDD1CB998EF019D.description: Explain the fundamental beliefs of abolitionism and compare the antislavery positions of the “immediatists” and “gradualists” within the movement. [Consider multiple perspectives]

0CD9C2C1E8BF4D0C956B857ACF512354.description: Abolition Movement: The student understands the abolitionist movement.

E6945FEA8BEA4BAC9A010BD1EC4A8BDE.description: Analyze how the debates over slavery–from agitation over the “gag rule” of the late 1830s through the war with Mexico–strained national cohesiveness and fostered rising sectionalism. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

C6F52C92414F4E7989791C920DDAD674.description: Explain how tariff policy and issues of states’ rights influenced party development and promoted sectional differences. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

887EFD19EB8A406E9A33D3DCE024E48F.description: Explain the Missouri Compromise and evaluate its political consequences. [Identify issues and problems in the past]

3A2DBFB974194A18A9A6F0A3724F7AB4.description: Slavery & Sectionalism: The student understands how the debates over slavery influenced politics and sectionalism.

8F529293C4084DEDA7D5829DCD749CC4.description: Evaluate the importance of state and local issues, the rise of interest-group politics, and the style of campaigning in increasing voter participation. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

948F69E55EC54E3EA230B8D7E1B6990F.description: Explain the combination of sectional, cultural, economic, and political factors that contributed to the formation of the Democratic, Whig, and “Know-Nothing” parties. [Analyze multiple causation]

3863992567434C11814C6A981358DAE9.description: Analyze how Jackson’s veto of the U.S. Bank recharter and his actions in the nullification crisis contributed to the rise of the Whig party. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

9AA094CBBACE4B78905F70DCBAB9CBE3.description: Relate the increasing popular participation in state and national politics to the evolving democratic ideal that adult white males were entitled to political participation. [Identify relevant historical antecedents]

9985192C00604689B45B8C81AEDA5337.description: Explain why the election of Andrew Jackson was considered a victory for the “common man.” [Assess the importance of the individual in history]

C9EC7D5D31784111BAC5A4398720B5BA.description: Analyze the influence of the West on the heightened emphasis on equality in the political process. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

732C08AAF3F243FD83D39A88B53B4420.description: Explain the contradictions between the movement for universal white male suffrage and the disenfranchisement of free African Americans as well as women in New Jersey. [Evaluate the implementation of a decision]

46C4DE5C6FA14333B56C5023CA699B3B.description: Early American Political LIfe: The student understands the changing character of American political life in “the age of the common man.”

7E7EE76486AE4C92ACCFFD940E158407.description: Assess the degree to which political democracy was a characteristic of the West and evaluate the factors influencing political and social conditions on the frontier. [Differentiate between historical facts and historical interpretations]

0080527437064B0BB0BD722B11DD6A67.description: Analyze cultural interactions among diverse groups in the trans-Mississippi region. [Consider multiple perspectives]

4D4DD2B72B594891937715AC5DE4CF8A.description: Examine the origins and political organization of the Mormons, explaining the motives for their trek west and evaluating their contributions to the settlement of the West. [Appreciate historical perspectives]

18E648FF2D384BC09EE42FB41D3B6D85.description: Contrast the causes and character of the rapid settlement of California and Oregon in the late 1840s and 1850s. [Compare and contrast different patterns of settlement]

ED9A32AB66A44932A033EBC3D89B484C.description: Explore the lure of the West and the reality of life on the frontier. [Examine the influence of ideas]

84F91931B2DC4D54AAA23DCC0D88B958.description: Western Settlement: The student understands the settlement of the West.

73D3F165580441538D66D4F52189ABAE.description: Analyze the argument that the institution of slavery retarded the emergence of capitalist institutions and values in the South. [Evaluate major debates among historians]

D422DF6AE30A4CCBBF6C37D8684B811F.description: Evaluate how enslaved African Americans used religion and family to create a viable culture and ameliorate the effects of slavery. [Obtain historical data]

6D4F2119B3924497B10C899BEC4B502A.description: Analyze the impact of the Haitian Revolution and the ending of the Atlantic slave trade. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

156F171C7D774DD195A060DBCC383379.description: Identify the various ways in which African Americans resisted the conditions of their enslavement and analyze the consequences of violent uprisings. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

7E456D9E259A4BFA8B1A44E6C748FDB0.description: Describe the plantation system and the roles of their owners, their families, hired white workers, and enslaved African Americans. [Consider multiple perspectives]

57B2F510DEFA43CBAE0225D7A4A1A79F.description: Explain how the cotton gin and the opening of new lands in the South and West led to the increased demand for slaves. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

DEF1C8B69716424CB02745B4467C9E68.description: African American Slavery: The student understands the rapid growth of “the peculiar institution” after 1800 and the varied experiences of African Americans under slavery

0A2DDCD4141541AEA3A51EF0139D1798.description: Explain how immigration intensified ethnic and cultural conflict and complicated the forging of a national identity. [Interrogate historical data]

42B76BA4B9894909BF1397D87AAF4A00.description: Assess the connection between industrialization and immigration. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

0F6A1029887D43D18BA324EC5EC18685.description: Assess the ways immigrants adapted to life in the United States and to the hostility sometimes directed at them by the nativist movement and the Know Nothing party. [Assess the importance of the individual in history]

04BC157720284B4381DFD87CDA2654C3.description: Analyze the push-pull factors which led to increased immigration, for the first time from China but especially from Ireland and Germany. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

9133E13E282544CA954D9965068E363C.description: Antebellum Immigration: The student understands how antebellum immigration changed American society.

CABF620A2382444FA7FDE5126BE15F2A.description: Explain the growth of free African American communities in the cities and account for the rise of racial hostility. [Examine the influence of ideas]

7030CF956FE24280A954FB46B011FA76.description: Analyze how rapid urbanization, immigration, and industrialization affected the social fabric of early 19th-century cities. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

BEFB8667B0624583923AC01CC3A3F86E.description: Identify and explain the factors that caused rapid urbanization and compare the new industrialized centers with the old commercial cities. [Explain historical continuity and change]

70891D3007164DE68A6B43CEFEA07B92.description: Compare popular and high culture in the growing cities. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

26AB62BE9BF54961949F4667DB6BA097.description: First Era of Urbanization: The student understands the first era of American urbanization.

A5BF4EAD66B149C487CBBEE253E801E0.description: Compare how patterns of economic growth and recession affected territorial expansion and community life in the North, South, and West. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

CFDF53B482F44485BBEEEF1AB9C1A9F6.description: Explain how economic policies related to expansion, including northern dominance of locomotive transportation, served different regional interests and contributed to growing political and sectional differences. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

D53FF532379F48668E8E0DEAAEB7E592.description: Evaluate the factory system from the perspectives of owners and workers and assess its impact on the rise of the labor movement in the antebellum period. [Consider multiple perspectives]

6C41DE07F3184112A10702517E417CE5.description: Evaluate national and state policies regarding a protective tariff, a national bank, and federally funded internal improvements. [Examine the influence of ideas]

B01FF6C3F0DC4327B96BDC3610FD39D6.description: Analyze how the factory system affected gender roles and changed the lives of men, women, and children. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

F3F640004D2C4ADFB33CABBD7011FAC7.description: Explain how the major technological developments that revolutionized land and water transportation arose and analyze how they transformed the economy, created international markets, and affected the environment. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

8769FB6C60674211A9352FF954B04C7A.description: Market & Factory Revolution: The student understands how the factory system and the transportation and market revolutions shaped regional patterns of economic development.

01DE86056E4D4E1F9D9329DC39BED475.description: Analyze different perspectives on the Mexican-American War. [Consider multiple perspectives]

FA5AD7DCA1C2480EA5540142D653E30D.description: Analyze United States trading interests in the Far East and explain how they influenced continental expansion to the Pacific. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

DD7DEC25E85740F7B5AF484F4DA0C99F.description: Explain the diplomatic and political developments that led to the resolution of conflicts with Britain and Russia in the period 1815-1850. [Formulate a position or course of action on an issue]

45C77C6A005547F2A946FB365A99868C.description: Explain the economic, political, racial, and religious roots of Manifest Destiny and analyze how the concept influenced the westward expansion of the nation. [Examine the influence of ideas]

416DCD7279DD4604A7B2ACAC8A6A0F1C.description: Explain the causes of the Texas War for Independence and the Mexican-American War and evaluate the provisions and consequences of the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo. [Analyze multiple causation]

72F746B0A3A349908DD54DE2225EFA2C.description: Compare and explain the peaceful resolution of the Oregon dispute with Great Britain and the declaration of war with Mexico. [Challenge arguments of historical inevitability]

44AB8E99F84D4A00B20C535C195D3A8E.description: Manifest Destiny: The student understands the ideology of Manifest Destiny, the nation’s expansion to the Northwest, and the Mexican-American War.

3E316DE9EF324C2986E6C6405EAEB70D.description: Compare federal and state Indian policy and explain Whig opposition to the removal of Native Americans. [Consider multiple perspectives]

E0A9E2E488B241C397F4CA6492E10CCB.description: Explain and evaluate the various strategies of Native Americans such as accommodation, revitalization, and resistance. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

EC0E0439B47647879E2093D5D53C4359.description: Compare the policies toward Native Americans pursued by presidential administrations through the Jacksonian era. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

246291324CDF4FD8B2A256C1E8DF119B.description: Investigate the impact of trans-Mississippi expansion on Native Americans. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

8AF2553269984638A53F7ADDF39434DF.description: Analyze the impact of removal and resettlement on the Cherokee, Creek, Chickasaw, Choctaw, and Seminole. [Appreciate historical perspectives]

04E91FAB90DA41959E1F4A51C896574B.description: Federal Indian Policy:- The student understands federal and state Indian policy and the strategies for survival forged by Native Americans.

72D27066C56D49EFBC40FED8D37CDAA2.description: Assess how the Louisiana Purchase affected relations with Native Americans and the lives of various inhabitants of the Louisiana Territory. [Explain historical continuity and change]

2B46CE6EE4BF431580618420E4EB7BCA.description: Analyze how the Louisiana Purchase influenced politics, economic development, and the concept of Manifest Destiny. [Evaluate the implementation of a decision]

C43AA37F339F44FBBB23B83C5D5F88D2.description: Compare the arguments advanced by Democratic Republicans and Federalists regarding the acquisition of Louisiana. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

BBF3095EC1D6434F9CB05906692A0F65.description: Identify the origins and provisions of the Monroe Doctrine and how it influenced hemispheric relations. [Reconstruct patterns of historical succession and duration]

7ED30829CFDE409486E49F14FC76E4D1.description: Assess why many Native Americans supported the British in the War of 1812 and the consequences of this policy. [Consider multiple perspectives]

9F33D459E7FF4EE183388814BBE28228.description: Explain President Madison’s reasons for declaring war in 1812 and analyze the sectional divisions over the war. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

F0377C432A1846368A1E02184B4E382A.description: Analyze Napoleon’s reasons for selling Louisiana to the United States. [Draw upon the data in historical maps]

553A8F1BFBE9429AB6945EF72D2ED0FB.description: Early American Foreign Policy: The student understands the international background and consequences of the Louisiana Purchase, the War of 1812, and the Monroe Doctrine.

11BAD3198D254FACA8FB874C127B509F.description: Explain the principles and issues that prompted Thomas Jefferson to organize an opposition party. [Analyze multiple causation]

F7712B61839F4F439D4E0FB23F1DBE07.description: Assess the influence of the French Revolution on American politics. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

4F3828B5B8744E789143DABA3B2D6F54.description: Compare the opposing views of the two parties on the main economic and foreign policy issues of the 1790s. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

023A94186CD24F9392E106F518750B88.description: Compare the leaders and social and economic composition of each party. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

8C650A18542246C6BFC484E846C504FB.description: America's First Political Parties: The student understands the development of the first American party system.

E00E7A7900D84AF5ACD903429C774CB3.description: Trace the evolution of the Supreme Court’s powers during the 1790s and early 19th century and analyze its influence today. [Explain historical continuity and change]

CAA2607E42E1428FB84BB6F0A19A3C3D.description: Appraise how John Marshall’s precedent-setting decisions interpreted the Constitution and established the Supreme Court as an independent and equal branch of the government. [Assess the importance of the individual]

7F7141A692104978B89A689E52766941.description: Building the Supreme Court: The student understands the development of the Supreme Court’s power and its significance from 1789 to 1820.

5424870C2F374A7EBEA301930BD3C99F.description: Analyze issues addressed in recent court cases involving the Bill of Rights to assess their continuing significance today. [Identify relevant historical antecedents]

84355E7C2E014E01B726650E8AB9EF39.description: Analyze whether the Alien and Sedition Acts of 1798 threatened First Amendment rights and the issues the Alien and Sedition Acts posed in the absence of judicial review of acts of Congress. [Evaluate the implementation of a decision]

C9C72E00E0D54CE2B7456F9D973E8BA3.description: Evaluate the arguments over the necessity of a Bill of Rights and explain Madison’s role in securing its adoption by the First Congress. [Assess the importance of the individual]

3D83DF28931E45759F85B119000C340C.description: Analyze the significance of the Bill of Rights and its specific guarantees. [Examine the influence of ideas]

CB958751A3644ACCA75EF09DD463D5F5.description: Bill of Rights: The student understands the guarantees of the Bill of Rights and its continuing significance.

4CAF0D15D7C2402E94D2870A58F4F6AA.description: Compare the arguments of Federalists and Anti-Federalists during the ratification debates and assess their relevance in late 20th-century politics. [Hypothesize the influence of the past]

8A0BE7CB94BC4EE988A595E44EE0E583.description: Analyze the fundamental ideas behind the distribution of powers and the system of checks and balances established by the Constitution. [Examine the influence of ideas]

490A1AC5B2B84F08AB05B66EDCFF8C47.description: Analyze the alternative plans considered by the delegates and the major compromises agreed upon to secure approval of the Constitution. [Examine the influence of ideas]

CE8C826AA48D4C9DA871D5526917B3B3.description: Analyze the factors involved in calling the Constitutional Convention. [Analyze multiple causation]

CCC43F20C1A5493995BE7BDD28CDD489.description: Analyze the features of the Constitution which have made this the most enduring and widely imitated written constitution in world history. [Examine the influence of ideas]

1C85C352808F421992D97A9515380913.description: Ratifying the Constitution: The student understands the issues involved in the creation and ratification of the United States Constitution and the new government it established.

1CE287F993CF4FD09550D2BBD29D77A7.description: Explain how African American leaders and African American institutions shaped free black communities in the North. [Assess the importance of the individual]

63382E4DA91246A8837792AB6E81CBF6.description: Compare the reasons why many white men and women and most African American and Native Americans remained loyal to the British. [Consider multiple perspectives]

62E37AE221214C83819C8D26A0D0BDE5.description: Analyze the ideas put forth arguing for new women’s roles and rights and explain the customs of the 18th century that limited women’s aspirations and achievements. [Examine the influence of ideas]

7D50731D8DC648E485AFD2877AA92E64.description: Explain the revolutionary hopes of enslaved and free African Americans and the gradual abolition of slavery in the northern states. [Examine the influence of ideas]

4C660F717524472F97DAC44EE05F8E3B.description: Compare the revolutionary goals of different groups—for example, rural farmers and urban craftsmen, northern merchants and southern planters—and how the Revolution altered social, political, and economic relations among them. [Compare and contrast differing values, behaviors, and institutions]

FE63E614B3854B4E9B38B6E84E86ECCD.description: Social Impact of Revolution: The student understands the Revolution’s effects on different social groups.

6F4B99728F424A8CADF8F244BDDAA418.description: Explain how the Continental Congress and the states attempted to rebuild the economy by addressing issues of foreign and internal trade, banking, and taxation. [Formulate a position or course of action on an issue]

50B4A54FE3104C1F887621138355E301.description: Explain the dispute over the western lands and evaluate how it was resolved. [Draw upon data in historical maps]

8872B8CDD7944A89A5881238B96B1488.description: Evaluate how the states and the Continental Congress dealt with the revolutionary war debt. [Utilize quantitative data]

9EA54409955647E899C8F47EE4646166.description: Analyze the factors that led to Shay’s Rebellion. [Analyze multiple causation]

3C656E74FCD542FAA4DBAD952D6C2561.description: Economic Issues of Revolution: The student understands the economic issues arising out of the Revolution.

53FCB441F52341B99F26F1BF36CCD0DA.description: Compare several state constitutions and explain why they differed. [Analyze multiple causation]

5BFB3D69CA9F4209A3F585711965B37A.description: Assess the importance of the Northwest Ordinance. [Interrogate historical data]

1363C3CBC3F64909B6C49E1BBB603268.description: Assess the accomplishments and failures of the Continental Congress. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

10370091D1C747639C3632D2DA82367F.description: Analyze the arguments over the Articles of Confederation. [Examine the influence of ideas]

1AF337826B974020B9DD54CEEA1EBAB8.description: Building A New Govt.:  The student understands revolutionary government-making at national and state levels.

37E8DECEC95449AC8F5FA1F01CEB3A3A.description: Analyze the problems of financing the war and dealing with wartime inflation, hoarding, and profiteering. [Identify issues and problems in the past]

073CCD564AF24D6E96059A5768C73F17.description: Analyze the terms of the Treaty of Paris and how they affected U.S. relations with Native Americans and with European powers that held territories in North America. [Consider multiple perspectives]

EC5D7292C2074F6C940CB3B7480D3B65.description: Explain how the Americans won the war against superior British resources. [Analyze multiple causation]

63A10B1CE49C451A9EEF2417E8724CC0.description: Analyze United States relationships with France, Holland, and Spain during the Revolution and the contributions of each European power to the American victory. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

6DE2992075654862A769BC88FAC48072.description: Compare and explain the different roles and perspectives in the war of men and women, including white settlers, free and enslaved African Americans, and Native Americans. [Evaluate the influence of ideas]

3B3ED1F0A50244B09372A8CF5797B3F1.description: Appraise George Washington’s military and political leadership in conducting the Revolutionary War. [Assess the importance of the individual]

180E6F6C43B24D95ABA447E1939D64AD.description: Revolutionary War: The student understands the factors affecting the course of the war and contributing to the American victory.

5D7706C90E8645F99549068F347BA37D.description: Compare the Declaration of Independence with the French Declaration of the Rights of Man and Citizen and construct an argument evaluating their importance to the spread of constitutional democracies in the 19th and 20th centuries. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

ACD24C6F46024564B13C894336B5A8C9.description: Draw upon the principles in the Declaration of Independence to construct a sound historical argument regarding whether it justified American independence. [Interrogate historical data]

D3DD84C85C174B2BA095CC0F7A698544.description: Demonstrate the fundamental contradictions between the ideals expressed in the Declaration of Independence and the realities of chattel slavery. [Consider multiple perspectives]

F7BA857613B5464B99913C080ECCAE06.description: Explain how key principles in the Declaration of Independence grew in importance to become unifying ideas of American democracy. [Evaluate the influence of ideas]

6DC746A4E98444608AAB541265CCFDDB.description: Explain the major ideas expressed in the Declaration of Independence and their intellectual origins. [Marshal evidence of antecedent circumstances]

0B733B2635EE4AF0BA292F53E0BD3B0E.description: Declaration of Independence: The student understands the principles articulated in the Declaration of Independence.

5DB37AB5B3F442E4853E2B9009003D7B.description: Reconstruct the arguments among patriots and loyalists about independence and draw conclusions about how the decision to declare independence was reached. [Consider multiple perspectives]

915AB53339D14A1397623956A7A29949.description: Analyze political, ideological, religious, and economic origins of the Revolution. [Analyze multiple causation]

5E02952958464D948D8DE8938653488D.description: Reconstruct the chronology of the critical events leading to the outbreak of armed conflict between the American colonies and England. [Establish temporal order]

DBC3D61DDD3341AD976AE0B580ACC672.description: Compare the arguments advanced by defenders and opponents of the new imperial policy on the traditional rights of English people and the legitimacy of asking the colonies to pay a share of the costs of empire. [Consider multiple perspectives]

7A577AC5BE294FED81AB394B2DC84C42.description: Explain the consequences of the Seven Years War and the overhaul of English imperial policy following the Treaty of Paris in 1763. [Marshal evidence of antecedent circumstances]

6D5A97575DD0447AAB0BA1F8889CEF36.description: Causes of Revolution: The student understands the causes of the American Revolution.

170FB7CBC5324AF89CFBEE24793B886E.description: Assess the contribution of enslaved and free Africans to economic development in different regions of the American colonies. [Interrogate historical data]

83798BF6298D45EC84EBCA40E6084C6F.description: Analyze overt and passive resistance to enslavement. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

DAE51095D96E4832A555F6172385E1C7.description: Analyze how Africans in North America drew upon their African past and upon selected European (and sometimes Indian) customs and values to develop a distinctive African American culture. [Identify gaps in the historical record while constructing a sound historical interpretation]

E519CF33B7C64C04982781EFC2804AAA.description: Explain how varieties of slavery in African societies differed from the chattel racial slavery that developed in the English colonies. [Compare and contrast differing institutions]

962F8B5C17324083B570F73E5AC88575.description: Analyze the forced relocation of Africans to the English colonies in North America and the Caribbean. [Appreciate historical perspectives]

AFBAECA42D004E6B81BF2EE3EF438274.description: Life of African Slave: The student understands African life under slavery

CBAE0A39E7BE4FED9B3E6041CBF66F09.description: Explore how the mobility and material success of many colonists encouraged the development of a consumer society and led to the imitation of English culture. [Utilize quantitative data]

36A518E3864E4A7F8DBDF522724E5048.description: Explain the shift from indentured servitude to chattel slavery in the southern colonies. [Challenge arguments of historical inevitability]

CAD9F657126647DAA4047D47C03F11BD.description: Compare the characteristics of free labor, indentured servitude, and chattel slavery. [Compare and contrast differing labor systems]

D30B328F14394CE2BEA49632848EA6FE.description: Analyze how the early Navigation Acts affected economic life in the colonies. [Marshal evidence of antecedent circumstances]

FE9C873A1D4C4ABA93A2C47CA0D3B25B.description: Explain how environmental and human factors accounted for differences in the economies that developed in the colonies of New England, mid-Atlantic, Chesapeake, and lower South. [Compare and contrast different sets of ideas]

2833D69D23F341A89D0E77AC447EFB18.description: Geography, Labor Systems & Culture: The student understands economic life and the development of labor systems in the English colonies.

671A6E4C232B4BCD8F502EAF7B2E3458.description: Explain the development of an Atlantic economy in the colonial period. [Reconstruct patterns of historical succession and duration]

110FEDBBEE044CADA32A43A49A3B9E9F.description: Explain mercantilism and evaluate how it influenced patterns of economic activity. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

44E04E088E5D4AC7A07FA8356EE0F378.description: Identify the major economic regions in the Americas and explain how labor systems shaped them. [Utilize visual and mathematical data]

DECA9471C3614936965348200C5B6CF8.description: Mercantilism & Triangular Trade: The student understands colonial economic life and labor systems in the Americas.

9D7440AF514242E7A4373F536ECAA396.description: Explore the seeds of public education in the New England colonies and explain how literacy and education differed between New England and southern colonies. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

53DBF68042794043BB77F1DB898387E3.description: Analyze women’s property rights before and after marriage in the colonial period. [Interrogate historical data]

FAE5EBE5942942AE8BFD0845BB2DCC30.description: Explain how rising individualism challenged inherited ideas of hierarchy and deference and affected the ideal of community. [Assess the importance of the individual]

EAF10CD4C31F4E45B2D400006CFA2ECA.description: Explain how and why family and community life differed in various regions of colonial North America. [Consider multiple perspectives]

BD055BED0B004B148AAE60EDFB01831A.description: Explain how Enlightenment ideas, including Benjamin Franklin’s experiments with electricity, influenced American society. [Examine the influence of ideas]

E20D1EA0C2264DF6A37A39C3EE56E380.description: English Colonial Society/Cultural Change: The student understands social and cultural change in British America.

0BB1620970C841AAA5F8EBD975B7693C.description: Describe religious groups in colonial America and the role of religion in their communities. [Consider multiple perspectives]

7A44052035F044748C12FFFA6EF50BBD.description: Explain the impact of the Great Awakening on colonial society. [Examine the influence of ideas]

0CCDC84F45B24796AED310FC28C9BC77.description: Trace and explain the evolution of religious freedom in the English colonies. [Reconstruct patterns of historical succession and duration]

64FFFDF69945487896E900304DF22289.description: Explain how Puritanism shaped New England communities and how it changed during the 17th century. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

222594598EA146D498E44CA956057E2E.description: Origins of Religious Diversity & Freedom: The student understands religious diversity in the colonies and how ideas about religious freedom evolved.

74E789B72BFA4ECA9C1366DCDA4B872F.description: Analyze how gender, property ownership, religion, and legal status affected political rights. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

9E109718F961459BA45EF609FC42FEE8.description: Explain how the conflicts between legislative and executive branches contributed to the development of representative government. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

C45F83BBD5FC45629BE593999E8C535C.description: Explain the social, economic, and political tensions that led to violent conflicts between the colonists and their governments. [Examine the influence of ideas]

599DEFC89E864952AADD110739D0EEC1.description: Explain the concept of the “rights of Englishmen” and the impact of the English Civil War and the Glorious Revolution on the colonies. [Hypothesize the influence of the past]

48ABDA1F2100452A8CFD5067DA9B2072.description: Analyze how the rise of individualism contributed to the idea of participatory government. [Assess the importance of the individual]

8121022B5D3F4CEFAE06D31214C28C52.description: Compare how early colonies were established and governed. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

0BCA4739025840A7BD61D8E2A20B5293.description: Roots of Representative Govt.: The student understands the roots of representative government and how political rights were defined.

846740BA919648DCBD290FD21CB2CB77.description: Analyze Native American involvement in the colonial wars and evaluate the consequences for their societies. [Consider multiple perspectives]

C0F8057C4CA74E3BA2C31658EF314E9F.description: Analyze the significance of the colonial wars before 1754 and the causes, character, and outcome of the Seven Years War. [Analyze multiple causation]

B77D89E8170F4A6AAEFC1D952F26E071.description: Analyze how various Native American societies changed as a result of the expanding European settlements and how they influenced European societies. [Examine the influence of ideas and interests]

7086BAE255F54BA4A2EACD18A9ABB8EC.description: Analyze relationships between Native Americans and Spanish, English, French, and Dutch settlers. [Compare and contrast different sets of ideas]

8E43476A7CB04562BF6F60753FACAD65.description: Compare how English settlers interacted with Native Americans in New England, mid-Atlantic, Chesapeake, and lower South colonies. [Consider multiple perspectives]

4D2CB83356884639ABAFF5D704947AE0.description: European Struggle for Americas: The student understands the European struggle for control of North America.

25C0B1226CE4442EB0D0E371DDE8568D.description: Compare the social composition of English, French, and Dutch settlers in the 17th and 18th centuries. [Interrogate historical data]

701B511AA14C4AD5AD14CADC9B77D0B8.description: Trace the arrival of Africans in the European colonies in the 17th century and the rapid increase of slave importation in the 18th century. [Reconstruct patterns of historical succession and duration]

94D9F318193F48EFA2A6C9B72A4F1F0D.description: Evaluate the opportunities for European immigrants, free and indentured, in North America and the Caribbean and the difficulties they encountered. [Compare competing historical narratives]

FD2AE41859DC42198E3EFB68651E1B68.description: Explain why so many European indentured servants risked the hardships of bound labor overseas. [Consider multiple perspectives]

BBC400E02FAA4D728546B2CD4EEB5900.description: Analyze the religious, political, and economic motives of free immigrants from different parts of Europe who came to North America and the Caribbean. [Consider multiple causation]

342A308D175D4106B26EC73D18A36D8D.description: Colonial Immigration: The student understands how diverse immigrants affected the formation of European colonies.

97600C6AB7DB498D8A9939C6A01B35FF.description: Describe the evolution and long-term consequences of labor systems such as encomienda and slavery in Spanish and Portuguese America. [Appreciate historical perspectives]

C90E25F368754F1BB9DC2FB1647AC95A.description: Analyze connections between silver mined in Peru and Mexico and the rise of global trade and the price revolution in 16th-century Europe. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

D638FACAA801499A8CC919F65A6528E1.description: Describe the social composition of the early settlers and compare their various motives for exploration and colonization. [Compare and contrast differing sets of ideas]

EE8F9B6136DA4389AC75183EE5809591.description: Explain and evaluate the Spanish interactions with such people as Aztecs, Incas, and Pueblos. [Examine the influence of ideas]

C8054D557D5D4E2CAE2CCE1A16B7C0B7.description: Spanish Conquest of Americas : The student understands the Spanish and Portuguese conquest of the Americas.

20806E8FA1F04E93BB80B400B4E20339.description: Appraise the role of national and religious rivalries in the age of exploration and evaluate their long-range consequences. [Consider multiple perspectives]

24C94464C74748C3858ED445CF99DFCD.description: Evaluate the course and consequences of the “Columbian Exchange.” [Hypothesize the influence of the past]

8A767781D9044683A5874AFB8AF6A63E.description: Evaluate the significance of Columbus’ voyages and his interactions with indigenous peoples. [Assess the importance of the individual in history]

3B2FE573975F42EBB3E4546F901DA9F7.description: Compare English, French, and Dutch motives for exploration with those of the Spanish. [Compare and contrast different sets of ideas]

5BECC98D40EA4A788C72E011B325D291.description: Trace routes taken by early explorers, from the 15th through the 17th century, around Africa, to the Americas, and across the Pacific. [Draw upon data in historical maps]

3601424F1B924BBF8A2ED332C6A58C58.description: Age of Exploration: The student understands the stages of European oceanic and overland exploration, amid international rivalries, from the 9th to 17th centuries.

8DEF34B022F54F17A58799409C14237C.description: Compare political systems, including concepts of political authority, civic values, and the organization and practice of government. [Compare and contrast different political systems

40ACD0FE95D54C119246E6B4AC466522.description: Compare dominant ideas and values including religious belief and practice, gender roles, and attitudes toward nature. [Compare and contrast the influence of ideas]

C826A1D291334EDDB9260CEC9D0A5AF2.description: Compare economic systems, including systems of labor, trade, concepts of property, and exploitation of natural resources. [Compare and contrast different economic institutions]

F688FFFFE42D4E99A09B2D82878482BF.description: Compare social organizations, including population levels, urbanization, family structure, and modes of communication. [Compare and contrast different social organizations]

41BCBB97BDE34D318B698B79DFBD57B3.description: Compare political systems, including concepts of political authority, civic values, and the organization and practice of government. [Compare and contrast different political systems]

0C3B7B3C186F43929D8F4D52A89C19B4.description: Three Worlds Collide: The student understands the differences and similarities among Africans, Europeans, and Native Americans who converged in the western hemisphere after 1492.

922D087323334781B61AD0184E41F46E.description: Analyze the varying responses of African states to early European trading and raiding on the Atlantic African coast. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

94EA97CFF4724CDC8EE2FAC14B4856F0.description: Analyze varieties of slavery in Western Africa and the economic importance of the trans-Saharan slave trade in the 15th and 16th centuries. [Analyze multiple causation]

92AC8A4EDCAA45849BB07B8CB18FCDCB.description: Describe the continuing growth of Islam in West Africa in the 15th and 16th centuries and analyze interactions between Islam and local religious beliefs and practices. [Examine the influence of ideas]

F033D5FC0AE1489295326D0631DBFE82.description: Describe the physical geography of West and Central Africa and analyze its impact on settlement patterns, cultural traits, and trade. [Draw upon data in historical maps]

7CC9D8661C33482DB78CED7728571084.description: West African Societies: The student understands developments in Western African societies in the period of early contact with Europeans.

76E5D29A528249B4B51A4773FDC4E546.description: Analyze relationships among the rise of centralized states, the development of urban centers, the expansion of commerce, and overseas exploration. [Identify historical antecedents]

2EB540227D164E748A8490BCFC011186.description: Describe major institutions of capitalism and analyze how the emerging capitalist economy transformed agricultural production, manufacturing, and the uses of labor. [Analyze cause-and-effect relationships]

35BB8CD47E8F416DA4D19B0D2DCE7036.description: Explain dissent within the Catholic Church and analyze the beliefs and ideas of leading religious reformers. [Explain the influence of ideas]

08698F5E66F64604B397BD2512331650.description: Explain the causes and consequences of European Crusades in Iberia and analyze connections between the Christian crusading tradition and European overseas exploration. [Analyze multiple causation]

660AFFE6F4C4440C861FEEA16EFC15D3.description: Appraise aspects of European society, such as family organization, gender roles, property holding, education and literacy, linguistic diversity, and religion. [Identify historical antecedents]

E8C7EAC4CFDE4D74876AC688F7FDC25F.description: Western Europe in the Age of Exploration: The student understands changes in Western European societies in the age of exploration.

857400A457154061840A82E5432D095F.description: Explain the common elements of Native American societies such as gender roles, family organization, religion, and values and compare their diversity in languages, shelter, labor systems, political structures, and economic organization. [Analyze multiple causation]

70FC485F583A4D33962BF74B078377E8.description: Explore the rise and decline of the Mississippian mound-building society. [Analyze multiple causation]

D541A188404E426386AD3C708BBA68E9.description: Trace the spread of human societies and the rise of diverse cultures from hunter-gatherers to urban dwellers in the Americas. [Reconstruct patterns of historical succession and duration]

A6FAA522909947FE900F2DB48B110216.description: Draw upon data provided by archaeologists and geologists to explain the origins and migration from Asia to the Americas and contrast them with Native Americans’ own beliefs concerning their origins in the Americas. [Compare and contrast different sets of ideas]

5BDC5D47F8954ABA935B759983701469.description: Pre-Columbian Societies: The student understands the patterns of change in indigenous societies in the Americas up to the Columbian voyages.
